docs.text: # Welcome to Aleksandr Michuda's website! I'm a graduate student in the Agricultural and Resource Economics Department at UC Davis . My interests include development economics, transparency in social science and using machine learning to solve infeasible problems.
docs.title: Home

docs.text: Aleksandr [Michuda]{.smallcaps} Personal Data ¶ [Address:]{.smallcaps} 602 Adams st. Apt. 18 \| Davis, CA 95616 [Phone:]{.smallcaps} 718-564-9741 [email:]{.smallcaps} <amichuda@ucdavis.edu> Education ¶ [PhD Candidate]{.smallcaps} University of California, Davis [Agriculture]{.smallcaps} [and Resource Economics]{.smallcaps} [Expected Graduation Date:]{.smallcaps} Summer 2021 [B.A./M.A. Economics]{.smallcaps} Hunter College [summa cum laude]{.smallcaps} [B.A. Philosophy]{.smallcaps} Languages and Skills ¶ [English:]{.smallcaps} Fluent [Russian:]{.smallcaps} Fluent [Ukrainian:]{.smallcaps} Basic Knowledge [Technical Skills:]{.smallcaps} Python, [STATA]{.smallcaps}, [matlab]{.smallcaps}, [mathcad]{.smallcaps}, LaTeX, R, Github, Bash \ \ Experience ¶ [BITSS Catalyst]{.smallcaps}- Berkeley Initiative for Transparency in the Social Sciences July 2017 - Present Organized workshops that teach reproducibility and transparency in social sciences. Taught Anonymization of data as well as replication techniques. Taught Jupyter Notebooks portion of dynamic documents (R Markdown, Jupyter Notebooks, Stata Markdown) [Graduate Research Assistant]{.smallcaps}- Advisor: Rachael E. Goodhue July 2016 - Present Responsible for data management and cleaning Regression and ANOVA analysis using Stata and Jupyter Notebooks Calibrating optimal stopping model and statistical models in Python Publications ¶ Cabanillas, Oscar Barriga, Jeffrey D. Michler, Aleksandr Michuda , and Emilia Tjernström. \"Fitting and interpreting correlated random-coefficient models using Stata.\" Stata Journal 18, no. 1 (2018): 159-173.\ Michuda, Aleksandr , Goodhue, Rachael, Klonsky, Karen, Baird, Graeme, Toyama, Lucinda, Zavatta, Margarita, & Shennan, Carol (2018). The economic viability of suppressive crop rotations for the control of verticillium wilt in organic strawberry production. Agroecology and Sustainable Food Systems, 1-25.\ Aleksandr Michuda , Rachael Goodhue, Joji Muramoto, and Carol Shennan. "Crop Rotations Can Increase Net Returns in Organic Strawberry and Vegetable Production Systems.\" ARE Update 20(6)(2017): 5-8. University of California Giannini Foundation of Agricultural Economics. Book Chapters ¶ Carter, M. R., & Michuda, A. (2019). The Distribution of Productive Assets and the Economics of Rural Development and Poverty Reduction. In The Palgrave Handbook of Development Economics (pp. 377-408). Palgrave Macmillan, Cham. Working Papers ¶ Labor Supply Adjustment to Adverse Agricultural Shocks: A Study of Uber and the Gig Economy\ Dissertation Topic In the developing world, there is little evidence on the added value of the flexibility provided by the gig economy We study the effects of shocks and as a way to see how flexibility in payment and choosing hours can aid in poverty alleviation. We use a novel method of connecting drivers to their rural places of origin using a machine learning classification using driver surnames We evaluate the existence of a shock based on a drought indices to find how adverse shocks affect labor supply behavior. "Revisiting Selection and Comparative Advantage in Technology Adoption: A Structural Approach.\" with Oscar Barriga Cabanillas, Jeffrey D. Michler, & Emilia Tjernström. Extending and improving the correlated random coefficients model by developing the "Group Random Coefficients" model. Providing a more robust approach to estimating heterogeneous effects of adoption that allows for over-identification tests and dynamic heterogeneity Conferences ¶ [AAEA Meetings 2019]{.smallcaps} Evaluating a Systems Approach to Suppressive Crop Rotations in Strawberry Production [AAEA Meetings 2018]{.smallcaps} Political Contributions and the Case of South African Land Reform [AAEA Meetings 2017]{.smallcaps} The Economic Viability of Suppressive Crop Rotations in Organic Strawberry Production Empirically Estimating the Impact of Weather on Agriculture [EEA Conference 2014]{.smallcaps} The Russian Mir and Agrarian Transition [CUNY's UGRC 2013]{.smallcaps} Large Frontiers and Coercion: An Economic Perspective Scholarships and Awards ¶ Hunter College {#hunter-college .unnumbered} ¶ \ [Fall]{.smallcaps} 2009 - [Spring]{.smallcaps} 2011 Philip and Aida Siff Educational Foundation Scholarship [Fall]{.smallcaps} 2009 - [Spring]{.smallcaps} 2011 Vallone Scholarship [All Semesters]{.smallcaps} Dean's List [Spring 2012]{.smallcaps} Undergraduate Research Initiative [Fall 2012]{.smallcaps} Roosevelt House Faculty Associate Travel and Research Grant [Spring 2013]{.smallcaps} Phi Sigma Tau (Philosophy Honor Society) Member [Spring 2013]{.smallcaps} The Scholarship and Welfare Fund Graduate Scholarship [Fall 2013]{.smallcaps} JMS Scholarship [Fall 2013]{.smallcaps} Eastern Economic Association Member [Spring 2014]{.smallcaps} William S. Bryar Memorial Award UC Davis {#uc-davis .unnumbered} ¶ \ [Fall 2014]{.smallcaps} - [Spring 2016]{.smallcaps} Steindler Fellowship [Spring 2017]{.smallcaps} Henry A. docs.text: Labor Supply Adjustment to Adverse Agricultural Shocks: A Study of Uber and the Gig Economy\ Dissertation Topic In the developing world, there is little evidence on the added value of the flexibility provided by the gig economy We study the effects of shocks and as a way to see how flexibility in payment and choosing hours can aid in poverty alleviation. We use a novel method of connecting drivers to their rural places of origin using a machine learning classification using driver surnames We evaluate the existence of a shock based on a drought indices to find how adverse shocks affect labor supply behavior. "Revisiting Selection and Comparative Advantage in Technology Adoption: A Structural Approach.\" with Oscar Barriga Cabanillas, Jeffrey D. Michler, & Emilia Tjernström. Extending and improving the correlated random coefficients model by developing the "Group Random Coefficients" model. Providing a more robust approach to estimating heterogeneous effects of adoption that allows for over-identification tests and dynamic heterogeneity
